data.title: Off and walking // TAC legislation sullies Boston Marathon

data.text:
BOSTON (AP) - A controversy over the validity of

the Boston Marathon course for record purposes appears to

have overshadowed the outstanding men's and women's fields

for Monday's race.

Technically, there are no world records for marathons, merely

world bests, because courses throughout the world are not

standardized.

But if any runner Monday goes under the men's world best

of 2 hours, 6 minutes, 50 seconds set by Belayneh Densimo

of Ethiopia at Rotterdam in 1988, or under the women's world

best of 2:21:06 by Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway at London

in 1985, it will not be recognized by the governing body

of the sport in the United States.

The reason? The Athletics Congress has passed legislation

that eliminated point-to-point records for road-race courses.

Under the legislation, courses that go downhill more than

one meter per kilometer (about 42 meters for a marathon)

or those in which the start and finish are farther apart

than 30 percent of the race distance (about eight miles)

do not count for record-keeping purposes. The Boston course

falls into both those categories.

The 26-mile, 385-yard point-to-point Boston course, from

suburban Hopkinton, Mass., to downtown Boston, drops approximately

150 meters.

Guy Morse, race director of the Boston Marathon, called

the new rule "overly stringent" and said it "should be

repealed."

TAC officials cite the need for conformity in records, and

emphasize they do not want to eliminate Boston marks from

the record books nor in any way discredit the 94-year-old

Boston Marathon.

The issue will come up for review in November at the TAC

convention in Seattle.

There are several runners in Monday's field who appear capable

of running under the world bests of Densimo and Kristiansen.

The men's lineup includes Tanzania's Juma Ikangaa, the world's

top-ranked marathoner in 1989, the runner-up in each of

the past two Boston marathons and last year's New York City

Marathon winner; Kenya's Ibrahim Hussein, the 1987 New York

City winner and 1988 Boston champion; Australia's Rob de

Castella, the 1986 Boston winner in a course-record 2:07:51;

Wales' Steve Jones, former holder of the world best and

the 1988 New York City champion, and Italy's Gelindo Bordin,

the 1988 Olympic gold medalist.

Also, Ethiopia's Zeleke Metafaria, the 1989 World Cup champion;

Tanzania's Simon Robert Naali, the 1989 Honolulu Marathon

champion; Mexico's Alejandro Cruz, the 1988 Chicago Marathon

winner, and former Boston winners Geoff Smith of Britain

(1984-85) and Greg Meyer of Grand Rapids, Mich. (1983).

Leading the women's field are Portugal's Rosa Mota, the

1988 Olympic gold medalist and 1987 and 1988 Boston winner;

Britain's Veronique Marot, the world's No. 2-ranked marathoner

and winner of the 1989 London Marathon; Spokane, Wash.,

resident Kim Jones, ranked third in the world and winner

of last year's Twin Cities Marathon; the Soviet Union's

Zoya Ivanova, the 1989 Los Angeles Marathon champion, and

Italy's Laura Fogli, two-time runner-up in the New York

City Marathon.
